Name: Question 1
Text: Where in the project lifecycle is your project currently at

Name: Question 1
Text: Which option best describes how is your application grouped and organised?

Answers.Name: Repository per an application
Answers.Conclusion: Conclusion A

Answers.Name: Repository per a group of applications
Answers.Conclusion: Conclusion A

Answers.Name: One repository with all applications
Answers.Conclusion: Conclusion B

Name: Question 2
Text: Which option best describes the most granular deployment you can do

Answers.Name: Every applications can be deployed individually
Answers.Conclusion: Conclusion A

Answers.Name: Groups of applications can be deployed together
Answers.Conclusion: Conclusion A

Answers.Name: All applications need to be deployed as one unit
Answers.Conclusion: Conclusion B

Name: Question 1
Text: How likely are your requirements going to change in the future?

Answers.Name: Unlikely
Answers.Conclusion: As your requirements are unlikely to change, there is less of the benifit gained from a microservice design.

Answers.Name: Very likely
Answers.Conclusion: As your requirements are likely to change, a microservice design may better suited to quickly adapting to change.

Name: Question 2
Text: How long is the expected lifespan of your project

Answers.Name: Short lifespan (1 year and under)
Answers.Conclusion: As the lifespan of your project is under a year, it may not be worth the additional work of breaking up your solution into modules

Answers.Name: Medium lifespan (1 - 3 years)
Answers.Conclusion: As you are conducting a projecty with a lifespan between 1 and 3 years it may still be worth breaking it up into microservices, but the longer the lifespan the more value added.

Answers.Name: Long lifespan (3+ years)
Answers.Conclusion: As you are conducting a project that is 3 years or longer, the investment in a microservice approach could allow for easier maintenance, faster deployments and modular scaling

Name: Question 3
Text: Is / will the application you are building part of a bigger eco system of applications or independent

Answers.Name: Independent
Answers.Conclusion: As the application you are building is independent with no direct connection to other applications it may be easier to build it as a more monolithic solution.

Answers.Name: Part of a bigger eco system of applicationd
Answers.Conclusion: As the application you are building is part of a wider suite of inter-connected applications it could be more valuable to develop the project as microservices.

Name: Question 4
Text: Do you need your applications components to be individually scalable.

Answers.Name: I do need individual components to be individually scalled
Answers.Conclusion: As the application you are building needs to be individually scaled it should be built using a microservice approach.

Answers.Name: All components can scale together
Answers.Conclusion: As the application you are building does not need to be individualy scalled, a monolith approach would still be suitable.

Name: Question 5
Text: How skilled is the team in building and designing microservices?

Answers.Name: Highly skilled
Answers.Conclusion: As your projects team are highly skilled in building microservices the chance of your team successfully building a microservice is high.

Answers.Name: Not highly skilled
Answers.Conclusion: As your projects team are not highly skilled in building microservices the chance of your team successfully building a microservice is lower.You may need to upskill.

Name: Question 6
Text: Do you have sufficient architectural team capacity to iteratively adapt architectural designs based on change?

Answers.Name: Good architectural capacity
Answers.Conclusion: As your project has sufficient capacity to handle iterative architectural change it would be able to handle a microservice approach where more architectural updates are likely.

Answers.Name: Low architectuaral capacity
Answers.Conclusion: As your project does not have sufficient capacity to handle iterative architectural change it be more likely to struggle keeping up with microservice iterative improvements.

Name: Question 7
Text: What best describes the size of your project?

Answers.Name: Small project
Answers.Conclusion: As your project is a smaller project it could be a more efficient use to time to make it monolithic.

Answers.Name: Large project
Answers.Conclusion: As your project is a larger project it would be more likely to benefit from a microservice architecture so that it can scale out across applications.

Name: Question 8
Text: What best describes the structure of your team working on the project

Answers.Name: One team building the entire appication
Answers.Conclusion: As your project is ran within one team a monolith approach would still be suitable.

Answers.Name: Multiple teams working on multiple parts of the app
Answers.Conclusion: As your project is ran in multiple sub-teams a microservice approach could make it easier for multiple teams to work together to build an application.

Name: Question 9
Text: Does your project use proprietory technologies?

Answers.Name: Yes my project does use proprietory technologies
Answers.Conclusion: As your project uses proprietory technologies a microservice approach may not be suitable.

Answers.Name: No my project does not use proprietary technologies
Answers.Conclusion: As your project does not use proprietory technologies, microservices would be more suitable.

Name: Question 10
Text: Does your project use agile methodologies?

Answers.Name: Yes my project uses agile methodologies
Answers.Conclusion: Microservices are better suited within agile environments.

Answers.Name: No my project uses agile methodologies
Answers.Conclusion: Agile methdodologies are better suited to the use of microservices.

Name: Question 11
Text: How frequent do you want/expect to have deployment

Answers.Name: 3 weeks or under
Answers.Conclusion: Projects with frequent deployments will find that microservices allows for smoother small deployments.

Answers.Name: Over 4 weeks
Answers.Conclusion: It is less imporant to be a microservice for projects that don't have frequent deployments.
